I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 2003 Country Strategy and Program for the Islamic 
Republic of Pakistan includes the provision of advisory technical assistance (TA) for capacity 
building  for  rural  development  of  the  Federally  Administered  Tribal  Areas  (FATA).1  The 
Government of Pakistan requested the TA to strengthen the planning and management capacity 
of key FATA development institutions, and FATA community-based organizations (CBO) to 
more effectively plan  and implement rural development activities including the FATA Rural 
Development Project, proposed for ADB financing in 2004. The ADB Fact-Finding  Mission 
visited Pakistan during 17 April–1 May 2003 and reached preliminary understanding with the 
Government on the objectives, scope, and implementation arrangements of the TA. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Development in the FATA significantly lags behind that of the adjoining settled districts 
of the North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) and the country as a whole, as reflected in the 
region's weak socioeconomic indicators. Government estimates are that as much as 60% of 
FATA households are below the poverty line. The region has a literacy rate of 17.4% and a 
primary school participation rate of 41.3%, which are significantly lower than the national 
averages of 45% and 77%, respectively. A mere 44% of the population has access to clean 
drinking water, as compared with 75% for the neighboring NWFP.  
 
3.  Key endogenous factors accounting for the limited pace of development include (i) 
limited availability of development funds; (ii) limited or nonexistent participation of civil society in 
development activities because of local administration managing the tribal affairs mostly through 
traditional community leaders (maliks); (iii) an ineffective centralized decision-making process 
for planning and implementing projects; (iv) limited or nonexistent monitoring of activities and 
outputs; and (v) generally weak capacities of the government line departments working in the 
FATA  for  planning,  implementing,  and  monitoring  development  interventions.  In  addition, 
fundamental governance and values issues impact the development process in the FATA. The 
issues  include  limited  transparency,  accountability,  commitment,  empathy,  and  equity  (in 
particular for marginalized segments of society including women and the poor). The TA will 
focus specifically on the capacities of government line departments, and the proposed FATA 
RDP will address, to the extent feasible, the full range of aforementioned endogenous factors.  
 
4.  Until mid-2002, FATA administration was managed by the NWFP Government. Along 
with the provincial government, the FATA Development Corporation (FATA DC)2 also undertook 
limited development work (in the areas of irrigation, industries, and minerals) in the FATA. 
Commencing in early 2002, the system of governance in the FATA has been changing as part 
of Government policy to bring the region into the mainstream economy and body politic. Among 
the changes was the abolition of the FATA DC in May 2002, under a federal cabinet decree, as 
part of the reorganization process, and the creation of the Governor's Secretariat for FATA (the 
Secretariat)  in  June  2002.  The  Secretariat,  established  by  the  governor  of  NWFP  (the 
Governor),  has  been  tasked  with  coordinating  and  funding  FATA  development  efforts.  In 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 27 March 2003.  
2 The FATA DC was established in the early 1970s within the Federal Ministry of States and Frontier Regions 
(SAFRON), which is the federal ministry with oversight responsible for FATA affairs.

2 
addition,  various  FATA-dedicated  line  departments  that  formerly  were  within  the  NWFP 
government structure have been consolidated under the Secretariat.3 
 
5.  A diagnostic study of the capacity of key levels of the FATA-specific government bodies 
in Peshawar and in Bajaur Tribal Agency identified major problems and constraints, including, 
but not limited to the following: (i) planning, monitoring and evaluation capacities are limited; (ii) 
line departments focus on reactive decision making as against the need for proactive actions; 
(iii)  little  or  no  information  is  provided  to  the  line  departments  in  the  FATA  on  resource 
availability for making short- and medium-term plans; and (iv) there are few accountability 
checks on the working of line departments. In addition, community development is not a priority. 
There is limited focus on facilitating beneficiary participation in development activities, linkage of 
line  departments  with  communities  is  limited,  and  development  information  is  not  made 
available to communities, resulting in distrust among farmers about government organizations. 
 
6.  The planning and development functions include preparation of development schemes in 
a consolidated form. Planning of development activities in the FATA is undertaken at the agency 
level and at the head offices of the FATA line agencies. The recent reorganization leading to the 
creation of the Secretariat has also led to decentralization of project preparation. Projects with 
investments up to about PRs40 million ($700,000) are prepared and approved by the Agency 
Development Sub-Committee, whose functions include (i) preparation of project documents 
(known as PC-1), (ii) planning and prioritization of development schemes, (iii) assessment of the 
feasibility of proposed schemes, and (iv) project performance monitoring. There are no planning 
and monitoring units at the head office level of the line departments working in the FATA. Thus 
the Secretariat-based line departments perform limited or no monitoring of activities undertaken 
in the FATA. The tribal agency-level staff of the line departments undertake some monitoring 
locally. This includes monitoring of achieving the targets of government project documents (PC-
1s) inputs and activities and not of outputs and achieving objectives.  
 
7.  The Secretariat-based Finance Department makes nondevelopment allocations for each 
line  department  in  the  FATA.  Line  department  heads  in  the  FATA  then  appropriate  the 
allocations made by the Secretariat Finance Department among individual functioning units and 
this  is  communicated  to  individual  units  as  well  the  office  of  the  Accountant  General. 
Appropriations are based on “demands” prepared earlier by the department heads for each unit. 
The financial management functions of line departments at the head office include preparation 
and consolidation of budgets; maintenance of accounts; and records relating to provident fund, 
pensions, and gratuities. Although the financial flow of funds are well established, the relevant 
staff require a clear understanding of the procedures and timely submission of demands for 
funding and follow-up of releases of funds from the Accountants Office. 
 
8.  Discussions with key officials in the Secretariat and the tribal agencies resulted in 
recommendations that the TA address weaknesses related to planning, implementation, and 
monitoring, as well as strengthening of sector-specific technical skills, and the effective use of 
information communication technology (ICT) systems. In view of the needs expressed and an 
assessment of the situation, there is significant scope for successful impact from the TA for

planning, monitoring, and managerial strengthening of the professional staff of line agencies 
working  in  the  FATA  and  responsible  for  broad-based  development  in  the  region,  and 
implementation of the proposed FATA RDP. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The TA purpose is to develop and facilitate among FATA officials and other stakeholders 
relevant skills, knowledge, and attitudes to achieve strategic objectives and to facilitate effective 
rural development in the FATA. A particular focus will be on strengthening the capabilities of the 
line  agencies  working  in  the  FATA  to  plan,  design,  manage,  monitor,  and  evaluate  rural 
development projects, with particular regard to the proposed loan-financed FATA RDP. This 
includes  agency  and  Secretariat-based  staff.  The  departments  involved  include  those  in 
planning and development,4 finance, livestock and dairy development; agriculture extension; 
local government and rural development; forestry department’ and works and services. A logical 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
10.  Expected outputs include (i) development of a more effective approach to planning and 
management that is appropriate to the institutional and resource capacity of the Secretariat and 
agency-based staff; (ii) strengthened coordination strategies and arrangements to optimize the 
effectiveness  of  development  activities  in  the  region;  and  (iii)  strengthened  financial 
management  systems  and  procedures  covering  planning,  budgeting,  and  cash  flow 
management  and  systems  and  procedures  to  monitor  financial  and  implementation 
performance.  
 
11.  Capacity-building efforts will also be undertaken to enhance the competence of select 
CBOs working in the three target FATA agencies. Efforts will focus on strengthening managerial 
and facilitation capacities of the CBOs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will have the following main activities: 
 
(i.)  Planning and monitoring. Key staff responsible for the preparation of PC-1s, 
monitoring, and reporting will be selected for training in planning, monitoring, and 
evaluation. The target group will be selected from the agency planning cells and 
relevant line departments in the three tribal agencies, as well as the Secretariat-
based  Finance  Department  staff  and  department  heads.  Training  will  be 
conducted through learning-by-doing, case studies in participatory workshops, 
and some formal classroom training. Accordingly, the TA will identify available 
training facilities and prepare training material and modules. Available training 
facilities  include  but  are  not  limited  to  the  Pakistan  Academy  for  Rural 
Development,  National  Rural  Support  Programme,  Institute  of  Management 
Sciences,  University  of  Peshawar,  and  Sarhad  Rural  Support  Programme's 
Human Resource Development Center. Local technical experts will be hired as 
needed to provide additional subject matter specialized training. 
 
                                                 
4 The proposed agency planning cells within the local government and rural development offices in the FATA will 
represent the Planning and Development Department of the Secretariat.

4 
(ii.)  Financial  management  and  budgeting.  The  financial  and  budgeting 
procedures and rules of business are well laid out but require familiarization for 
decision makers within the Secretariat and FATA-based line departments. Short-
term training will be provided in finance, budgeting, and auditing procedures for 
the  development  and  the  nondevelopment  fund  releases  and  reporting  of 
expenses.  
 
(iii.)  Familiarization with ADB policies, procedures, and guidelines. The TA will 
familiarize the Secretariat and relevant FATA-based line department staff with 
ADB's  safeguard  policies  and  procedures,  guidelines  and  procedures  for 
procurement,  consultant  selection  procedures,  project  financial  management, 
etc. 
 
(iv.)  CBO  strengthening.  CBOs  in  the  FATA  are  not  necessarily  development 
focused or professionally managed. Their present forms and structures need to 
be identified and then built to a level leading to community participation in 
development projects. This is a task for the  long-term TA provided under the 
FATA RDP. However, for short-term measures could be taken for identifying 
some NGOs and their services that can be used for strengthening CBOs. 
 
(v.)  Stakeholders  consultations  and  participation.  Decision  making  seldom 
involves consultations with or participation of beneficiaries (including women) and 
line department field workers at the grass roots level. A case study approach for 
training line department professional staff of the tribal agency and Secretariat 
levels should  be followed, as well as other relevant training and sensitization 
approaches. Requisite workshops conducted at the field level would benefit from 
the participation of the grass roots field workers of line departments. 
 
(vi.)  Information,  communication  technology  (ICT).  The  TA  will  identify 
approaches to address needs, provide training requirements, and contract ICT-
related organizations.  
 
13.  Training will be undertaken through participatory workshops and classroom training. Key 
personnel to be responsible for project management, especially for the proposed FATA RDP, 
will be identified for intensive on-the-job training during TA implementation. The TA also will 
develop course modules, materials, and manuals to be used by the trainees and refined for use 
by the proposed FATA RDP. All training activities must be recorded, trainee performance  
monitored and evaluated, and recommendations made for staff replacement, as necessary. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $605,000 equivalent, consisting of $143,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $462,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide 
$465,000 equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $322,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis under ADB's TA funding program. 
The Government will provide the remaining local currency cost of $140,000 equivalent, mainly 
for counterpart staff and other support services, office accommodation and facilities, equipment, 
and local transport. Detailed cost estimates are found in Appendix 2.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  To ensure the success of up-front capacity building, the Government must put in place 
dedicated counterpart staff units. This institutional arrangement is crucial, as even if there are 
changes in personnel later, some of the experience and learning will be retained and trickle 
down.  Indeed,  appointment  of  a  project  director  and  establishment  of  a  core  project 
management unit will be a condition for negotiations on the loan for the proposed FATA RDP, 
scheduled for approval in 2004. Accordingly, early establishment of the unit is essential so that 
the  appointed  staff  can  directly  interact  with  the  TA  consultants  and  undertake  the  rural 
development project preparatory work. 
 
16.  The Secretariat will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and will (i) be responsible for 
overall  coordination  with  ADB,  (ii)  provide  full  administrative  and  technical  support  to  the 
consultants, (iii) coordinate all project activities with the relevant FATA Agencies, and (iv) 
provide  for  the  consultants  requisite  office  space  with  appropriate  communication  means. 
Cooperation will be maintained, where necessary, with any consultants under the proposed 
FATA RDP. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, commencing in April 2004 and ending in 
September 2005. ADB will recruit, under the quality- and cost-based selection method and 
using the simplified technical proposal, a firm or consortium of international and domestic 
consultants  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic consultants. A total of 6 
person-months of international (institutional and local governance expertise) and 29 person-
months of domestic experts (in project management; training; financial management; planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation; community development; and ICT) will be required. Allocations are 
also made for additional training needs, to be identified during TA implementation, for which 
local technical experts will be hired as needed by the TA team on a daily rate basis. These 
allocations are for 100 person-days. Finally, block allocations are provided for in-country training 
institutes for training needs identified during the TA implementation. Appendix 3 provides the 
outline terms of reference for consulting services. Equipment will be procured in accordance 
with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
18.  The consultants' reporting requirements will include (i) a brief inception report within 3 
weeks of TA commencement, (ii) quarterly progress reports, (iii) a draft final report summarizing 
the achievements of the TA, and (iv) a final report based on revisions to the draft final report. 
The team leader and deputy team leader will be responsible for preparing and submitting the 
requisite  reports  to  the  Government  and  ADB.  In  the  course  of  TA  implementation,  the 
consultants will organize training programs and workshops in Peshawar and the tribal agencies, 
as appropriate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $465,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for Capacity Building for Rural Development of the Federally 
Administered Tribal Areas, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

7.  Communication and Information, Communication and Technology Specialist  (2 
person-months) 
 
7.  The specialist will do the following: 
(i)  identify information and communication facilities at the tribal agency level and 
undertake a need assessment of the line departments involved in implementing 
the FATA RDP; 
(ii)  identify the available ICT facilities in Peshawar for training the tribal agency line 
departments and the Secretariat staff; 
(iii)  in consultation with the team leader, other TA team members, and the project 
director, train relevant staff in ICT on-the-job  and  through  the  available  ICT 
facilities in the private sector in NWFP; and 
(iv)  assist the team leader in preparing a comprehensive  community development 
training-related report as an input for the RDP’s long-term support for institution-
building interventions.
